origin: Late 16th century from Turkish kahveh, from Arabic qahwa, probably via Dutch koffie.

noun.definition: A hot drink made from the roasted and ground seeds (coffee beans) of a tropical shrub.
The shrub which yields coffee seeds, native to the Old World tropics.

origin: Mid 17th century probably via Malay from Chinese (Min dialect) te; related to Mandarin chá. Compare with char.

noun.definition: A hot drink made by infusing the dried crushed leaves of the tea plant in boiling water.
A light afternoon meal consisting typically of tea to drink, sandwiches, and cakes.
noun.example: they were about to take afternoon tea

verb.definition: Drink tea or take afternoon tea.

noun.definition: An electronic device for storing and processing data, typically in binary form, according to instructions given to it in a variable program.

origin: Old English bōc (originally also ‘a document or charter’), bōcian ‘to grant by charter’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch boek and German Buch, and probably to beech (on which runes were carved).

noun.definition: A written or printed work consisting of pages glued or sewn together along one side and bound in covers.
A bound set of blank sheets for writing in.
A set of tickets, stamps, matches, samples of cloth, etc., bound together.

verb.definition: Reserve (accommodation, a place, etc.); buy (a ticket) in advance.
verb.example: I have booked a table at the Swan

verb.definition: Make an official note of the personal details of (a person who has broken a law or rule)
verb.example: the cop booked me and took me down to the station
they just ate your pizza and drank your soda and booked
